Balmoral CastleIPAc-enbælˈmɒrəlis a largeestate houseinRoyal Deeside,Aberdeenshire, Scotland. It is located near the village ofCrathie,convert6.2miwest ofBallaterandconvert6.8mieast ofBraemar.

Balmoral has been one of theList of British royal residencesresidencesfor members of theBritish Royal Familysince 1852, when the estate and its original castle were purchased privately byAlbert, Prince ConsortPrince Albert,Prince ConsortconsorttoQueen Victoria. They remain as the private property of the royal family and are not the property ofthe Crown.

Soon after the estate was purchased by the royal family, the existing house was found to be too small and the current Balmoral Castle was commissioned. The architect wasWilliam Smith (architect)William Smithof Aberdeen, although his designs were amended by Prince Albert.

The castle is an example ofScots Baronialarchitecture, and is classified byHistoric Scotlandas acategory A listedbuilding.cite webhttp://portal.historic-scotland.gov.uk/designation/LB51460BALMORAL CASTLE WITH PARTERRE AND TERRACE WALLS[[Historic Scotland]]26 October 2015The new castle was completed in 1856 and the old castle demolished shortly thereafter.

The BalmoralEstate (land)Estatehas been added to by successive members of the royal family, and now covers an area of approximatelyconvert50,000acreha. It is a working estate, includingRed Grousegrouse moors, forestry, and farmland, as well as managed herds of deer,Highland cattle, and ponies.
article.heading: History

link.part: After 1830, Sir Robert Gordon made major alterations to the original castle - ''lithograph by Josef Kriehuber, 1846''

article.paragraph: Robert II of ScotlandKing Robert IIof Scotland (13161390) had ahuntinghunting lodgein the area. Historical records also indicate that a house at Balmoral was built by Sir William Drummond in 1390.cite webhttp://www.whichcastle.com/aberdeenshire/balmoralcastle.htmBalmoral Castle, Aberdeenshirewww.whichcastle.com4 December 2010

The estate is recorded in 1451 as "Bouchmorale", and later was tenanted by Alexander Gordon, second son of theAlexander Gordon, 1st Earl of Huntly1st Earl of Huntly. Atower houses in Britain and Irelandtower housewas built on the estate by the Gordons.cite webhttp://www.historic-scotland.gov.uk/index/heritage/gardens/gardenssearchmoreinfo.htm?shttp://web.archive.org/web/20110629135631/http://www.historic-scotland.gov.uk/index/heritage/gardens/gardenssearchmoreinfo.htm?s2011-06-29Balmoral Castle: Site History archived at web.archive.orgAn Inventory of Gardens and Designed Landscapes in ScotlandHistoric Scotland18 June 2014Tower houses often are referred to ascastlesbecause of their formidable construction.

In 1662 the estate passed toCharles FarquharsonofInverey, brother ofJohn Farquharson, 3rd of InvereyJohn Farquharson, the "Black Colonel". The Farquharsons werejacobitismJacobitesympathisers, and James Farquharson of Balmoral was involved in both the 1715 and 1745Jacobite risingsrebellions. He was wounded at theBattle of Falkirk (1746)Battle of Falkirkin 1746.

The Farquharson estates werewikt:forfeitforfeit, and passed to the Farquharsons ofBraemarAuchendryne.cite book[[Seton Gordon|Gordon, Seton]]Seton Gordon's Cairngorms : an anthologyWhittles2009The Country of Balmoral141–142978-1-904445-88-3In 1798,James Duff, 2nd Earl Fife, acquired Balmoral and leased the castle.

Robert Gordon (diplomat)Sir Robert Gordon, a younger brother of theGeorge Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen4th Earl of Aberdeen, acquired the lease in 1830. He made major alterations to the original castle at Balmoral, including baronial-style extensions that were designed byJohn Smith (architect)John Smithof Aberdeen.
article.heading: Royal acquisition
article.paragraph: Queen Victoria and Prince Albert first visited Scotland in 1842, five years after her accession to the throne and two years after their marriage. During this first visit they stayed atEdinburgh, and atTaymouth CastleinPerthshire, the home of theJohn Campbell, 2nd Marquess of BreadalbaneMarquess of Breadalbane.They returned in 1844 to stay atBlair Castleand, in 1847, when they rented Ardverikie byLoch Laggan.Millar, pp.23,31During the latter trip they encountered weather that was extremely rainy, which ledJames Clark (physician)Sir James Clark, the queen's physician, to recommendRiver Dee, AberdeenshireDeesideinstead, for its more healthy climate.Millar, p.39

Sir Robert Gordon died in 1847 and his lease on Balmoral reverted to Lord Aberdeen. In February 1848 an arrangement was madethat Prince Albert would acquire the remaining part of the lease on Balmoral, together with its furniture and staffwithout having seen the property first.rp5

link.part: Coronation portrait of Victoria - ''by George Hayter, 1837''

article.paragraph: The royal couple arrived for their first visit on 8 September 1848.Millar, pp.4041Victoria found the house "small but pretty",Millar, p.41and recorded in her diary that: "All seemed to breathe freedom and peace, and to make one forget the world and its sad turmoils".The surrounding hilly landscape reminded them ofThuringia, Albert's homeland in Germany.rp5

Quickly, the house was confirmed to be too small and, in 1848, John and William Smith were commissioned to design new offices, cottages, and other ancillary buildings.Improvements to the woodlands, gardens, and estate buildings also were being made, with the assistance of the landscape gardener, James Beattie, and possibly by the painter,james Giles (painter)James Giles.

Major additions to the old house were considered in 1849,Millar, p.55but by then negotiations were under way to purchase the estate from the trustees of the deceased Earl Fife. After seeing acorrugated ironcottage at theGreat Exhibition of 1851, Prince Albert ordered a pre-fabricated iron building for Balmoral from E. T. Bellhouse & Co., to serve as a temporary ballroom and dining room.cite webhttp://www.stats.uwo.ca/faculty/bellhouse/chapter4.pdfE.T. Bellhouse and Co. Engineers and Iron FoundersDavid Bellhouse and Sons, ManchesterBellhouse, David200023 January 2012It was in use by 1 October 1851, and would serve as a ballroom until 1856.Millar, p.59

The sale was completed in June 1852, the price being 32,000, and Prince Albert formally took possession that autumn.rp8Millar, p.56The neighbouring estate ofBirkhallwas bought at the same time, and the lease onAbergeldie Castlesecured as well. To mark the occasion, thePurchase Cairnwas erected in the hills overlooking the castle, the first of many.
article.heading: Construction of the new house

link.part: ''Balmoral Castle'' - a principalkeepsimilar to that ofCraigievar Castleis the central feature of the castle, while a largeturretedScottish estate housescountry houseis attached

article.paragraph: The growing family of Victoria and Albert, the need for additional staff, and the quarters required for visiting friends and official visitors such as cabinet members, however, meant that extension of the existing structure would not be sufficient and that a larger house needed to be built. In early 1852, this was commissioned from William Smith.The son of John Smith (who designed the 1830 alterations of the original castle), William Smith was city architect ofAberdeenfrom 1852. On learning of the commission,William Burnsought an interview with the prince, apparently to complain that Smith previously had plagiarised his work, however, Burn was unsuccessful in depriving Smith of the appointment.cite webhttp://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?idWilliam Smith IIDictionary of Scottish Architects 1840–198023 January 2012William Smith's designs were amended by Prince Albert, who took a close interest in details such as turrets and windows.Millar, p.57

link.part: ''Balmoral Castle'', painted by Queen Victoria in 1854 during its construction

article.paragraph: Construction began during summer 1853, on a site someconvert100ydnorthwest of the original building that was considered to have a better vista.Millar, pp.5657Another reason for consideration was, that whilst construction was ongoing, the family would still be able to use the old house.rp9Queen Victoria laid the foundation stone on 28 September 1853, during her annual autumn visit.Millar, p.58By the autumn of 1855, the royal apartments were ready for occupancy, although the tower was still under construction and the servants had to be lodged in the old house.By coincidence, shortly after their arrival at the estate that autumn, news circulated about the fall ofSiege of Sevastopol (185455)Sevastopol, ending the Crimean War, resulting in wild celebrations by royals and locals alike. While visiting the estate shortly thereafter,Frederick III, German EmperorPrince Frederick of Prussiaasked for the hand ofVictoria, Princess RoyalPrincess Victoria.rp11

link.target: File:Queen Victoria Prince Albert and their nine children.JPG
link.part: alt=Photograph of a seated Victoria, dressed in black, holding an infant with her children and Prince Albert standing around her
With their nine children, 1857 - ''left to right'': Alice, Arthur, Prince Albert, Edward, Leopold, Louise, Queen Victoria holding Beatrice, Alfred, Victoria, and Helena

article.paragraph: The new house was completed in 1856, and the old castle subsequently was demolished.By autumn 1857, a new bridge across the Dee, designed byIsambard Kingdom Brunellinking Crathie and Balmoral was finished.rp11

Balmoral Castle is built fromgranitequarried at Invergelder on the estate,cite bookScotland's GardensLittle, G. A.Spur Books19810-7157-2091-0It consists of two main blocks, each arranged around a courtyard. The southwestern block contains the main rooms, while the northeastern contains the service wings. At the southeast is anconvert80ftmontall clock tower topped with turrets,one of which has a balustrade similar to a feature atCastle Fraser.cite bookFenwick, HubertScotland's Historic Buildings0-7091-4497-0Robert Hale1974Being similar in style to the demolished castle of the 1830s, the architecture of the new house is considered to be somewhat dated for its time when contrasted with the richer forms ofScots Baronialbeing developed by William Burn and others during the 1850s.cite bookGlendinning, MilesMacKechnie, AonghusMacInnes, RanaldA History of Scottish Architecture270Edinburgh University Press0-7486-0849-41996As an exercise in Scots Baronial, it sometimes is described as being too ordered, pedantic, and even,Architecture of GermanyGermanicas a consequence of Prince Albert's influence on the design.

The purchase of a Scottish estate by Victoria and Albert and their adoption of a Scottish architectural style, however, was very influential for the ongoing revival ofHighland culture. The royals decorated Balmoral with tartans and attendedhighland gamesat Braemar. Queen Victoria expressed an affinity for Scotland, even professing herself to be aJacobitismJacobite.cite bookDevine, T.M.The Scottish Nation 1700–2000Penguin2006978-0-14-102769-2Added to the work ofSir Walter Scott, this became a major factor in promoting the adoption ofHighland culturebyLowland ScotlandLowland Scots. Historian Michael Lynch comments that "the Scottishness of Balmoral helped to give the monarchy a truly British dimension for the first time".cite bookLynch, MichaelScotland: A New HistoryPimlico1992978-0-7126-9893-1
article.heading: Victoria and Albert at Balmoral
article.paragraph: Even before the completion of the new house, the pattern of the life of the royal couple in the Highlands was soon established. Victoria took long walks of up to four hours daily and Albert spent many days hunting deer and game. In 1849 the diarist,Charles Greville (diarist)Charles Greville, described their life at Balmoral as resembling that of gentry rather than royalty.Millar, p.44Victoria began a policy of commissioning artists to record Balmoral, its surroundings, and its staff. Over the years, numerous painters were employed at Balmoral, includingEdwin LandseerEdwinandCharles Landseer,Carl Haag,William Wyld,William Henry Fisk, and many others.Millar,passimThe royal couple took great interest in their staff. They established a lending library.

During the 1850s, new plantations were established near the house and exotic conifers were planted on the grounds. Prince Albert had an active role in these improvements, overseeing the design ofparterres, the diversion of the main road north of the river via a new bridge, and plans for farm buildings.These buildings included amodel farmmodel dairythat he developed during 1861, the year of his death. The dairy was completed by Victoria. Subsequently, she also built several monuments to her husband on the estate. These include a pyramid-shaped cairn built a year after Albert's death, on top ofCraig Lurachain. A large statue of Albert with a dog and a gun byWilliam Theed, was inaugurated on 15 October 1867, the twenty-eighth anniversary of their engagement.cite bookMacLeanCharlesBalmoral Highland EstateBalmoral Castle and Estaterp20–21Millar, p.102

link.part: Memorial cairn for Prince Albert, Balmoral Estate

article.paragraph: Following Albert's death, Victoria spent increasing periods at Balmoral, staying for as long as four months a year during early summer and autumn. Few further changes were made to the grounds, with the exception of some alterations to mountain paths, the erection of various cairns and monuments, and the addition of some cottages (Karim CottageandBaile na Coille) built for senior staff.rp18It was during this period that Victoria began to depend on her servant,John Brown (servant)John Brown. He was a localghilliefrom Crathie, who became one of her closest companions during her long mourning.rp23

In 1887, Balmoral Castle was the birthplace ofVictoria Eugenie of BattenbergVictoria Eugenie, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria. She was born toPrincess Beatrice of the United KingdomPrincess Beatrice, the fifth daughter of Victoria and Albert. Victoria Eugenie would become the queen of Spain.

In September 1896, Victoria welcomedNicholas II of RussiaEmperor Nicholas II of RussiaandAlexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)Empress Alexandrato Balmoral. Four years later Victoria made her last visit to the estate, three months before her death on 22 January 1901.
article.heading: After Victoria

link.part: ''Edward VIIrelaxing at Balmoral Castle'' - photograph by his wife, Alexandra, c. 1907-1908

article.paragraph: After Victoria's death, the royal family continued to use Balmoral during annual autumn visits.George Vhad substantial improvements made during the 1910s and 1920s, including formal gardens to the south of the castle.

During theSecond World War, royal visits to Balmoral ceased. In addition, due to the enmity with Germany,Danzig Shiel, a lodge built by Victoria in Ballochbuie was renamedGarbh Allt Shieland the "King of Prussia's Fountain" was removed from the grounds.rp25
Since the 1950s,Prince Philip, Duke of EdinburghPrince Philiphas added herbaceous borders and a water garden. During the 1980s new staff buildings were built close to the castle.
article.heading: Ownership
article.paragraph: Balmoral is a private property and, unlike the monarch'sofficial residences, is not the property ofthe Crown. It originally was purchased personally by Prince Albert, rather than the queen, meaning that no revenues from the estate go to Parliament or to the public purse, as otherwise in accord with theCivil List Act 1760would be the case for property owned outright by the monarch.

Along withSandringham Housein Norfolk, ownership of Balmoral was inherited byEdward VIIIon his accession in 1936. When heEdward VIII abdication crisisabdicatedlater the same year, however, he retained ownership of them. A financial settlement was devised, under which Balmoral and Sandringham were purchased by Edward's brother and successor to the Crown,George VI.cite webhttp://www.royal.gov.uk/TheRoyalResidences/SandringhamHouse/History.aspxSandringham House: HistoryThe official website of The British MonarchyThe Royal Household23 January 2012

Currently, the estate is still owned outright by the monarch, but, by Trustees under Deeds of Nomination and Appointment, it is managed by a trust.cite bookWightmanAndyThe Poor Had No Lawyers2011BirlinnEdinburgh113
article.heading: The estate
Current extent and operation
article.paragraph: Balmoral Estate is within theCairngorms National Parkand is partly within the Deeside and LochnagarNational Scenic Area (Scotland)National Scenic Area.cite webhttp://www.balmoralcastle.com/conservation.htmhttp://web.archive.org/web/20120805162711/http://www.balmoralcastle.com/conservation.htm2012-08-05ConservationBalmoral Estates (archived at web.archive.org18 June 2014Theconvert50,000acreonestate contains a wide variety of landscapes, from theRiver Dee, AberdeenshireDee river valleyto open mountains. There are sevenMunros(hills in Scotland overconvert3000ft) within the estate, the highest beingLochnagaratconvert3789ft. This mountain was the setting for a children's story,The Old Man of Lochnagar, told originally byCharles, Prince of WalesPrince Charlesto his younger brothers,Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkAndrewandPrince Edward, Earl of WessexEdward. The story was published in 1980, with royalties accruing toThe Prince's Trust.rp35–51Royal Collection1101076The Old Man of Lochnagar, 1980The estate also incorporates the 7,500-acreDelnadamph Lodgeestate, bought by Elizabeth II in 1978."The Queen buys grouse moor near Balmoral."The Times, London, 6 Jan. 1978: pg 3.
The estate extends toLoch Muickin the southeast where an old boat house and the RoyalBothy(hunting lodge) now namedGlas-allt Shiel, built by Victoria, are located.

The working estate includesRed Grousegrouse moors, forestry, and farmland, as well as managed herds of deer,Highland cattle, and ponies.rp38–47It also offers access to the public for fishing (paid) and hiking during certain seasons.rp36–37

Approximately 8,000 acres of the estate are covered by trees, with almost 3,000 acres used for forestry that yields nearly 10,000 tonnes of wood per year.Ballochbuie Forest, one of the largest remaining areas of old Caledonian pine growth in Scotland, consists of approximately 3,000 acres. It is managed with only minimal or no intervention.rp48,51The principal mammal on the estate is thered deerwith a population of 2,000 to 2,500 head.rp44

The areas of Lochnagar and Ballochbuie were designated in 1998 by theSecretary of State for ScotlandasSpecial Protection Areas(SPA) under the European Union (EU)Birds Directive.cite webhttp://www.jncc.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9002281.pdfLochnagar SPA: Standard Data Form[[Joint Nature Conservation Committee]]cite webhttp://www.jncc.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9002781.pdfBallolchbuie SPA: Standard Data FormJoint Nature Conservation CommitteeBird species inhabiting the moorlands includered grouse,black grouse,ptarmigan, and thecapercaillie.rp38Ballochbuie also is protected as aSpecial Area of Conservationby the EUHabitats Directive, as "one of the largest remaining continuous areas of nativeCaledonian Forest".cite webhttp://www.jncc.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCodeBallolchbuie SAC: Site DetailsJoint Nature Conservation CommitteeIn addition, there are fourSite of Special Scientific Interestsites of special scientific intereston the estate.

The royal family employs approximately 50 full-time and 50100 part-time staff to maintain the working estate.cite webhttp://www.balmoralcastle.com/employment.htmhttp://web.archive.org/web/20130115061807/http://www.balmoralcastle.com/employment.htm2013-01-15EmploymentBalmoral Estates archived at web.archive.org18 June 2014ASingle malt whiskymalt whiskydistillery located on the Balmoral Estate produces theRoyal Lochnagar Single Maltwhisky.

There are approximately 150 buildings on the estate,rp35includingBirkhall, formerly home toQueen Elizabeth The Queen Mother, and used now by Prince Charles and theCamilla, Duchess of CornwallDuchess of Cornwallfor their summer holidays.cite webhttp://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/personalprofiles/residences/birkhall/BirkhallThe Prince of Wales official websiteHousehold of HRH The Prince of Wales23 January 2012Craigowan Lodge is used regularly by the family and friends of the royal family and also has been used while Balmoral Castle was being prepared for a royal visit.Six smaller buildings on the estate are let asholiday cottages.cite webhttp://www.balmoralcastle.com/availability.htmCurrent AvailabilityBalmoral Estates23 January 2012
article.heading: Public access to gardens and castle grounds
article.paragraph: In 1931, the castle gardens were opened to the public for the first time and they now are open daily between April and the end of July, after which Queen Elizabeth arrives for her annual stay.cite webhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-357891/Castle-siege-tourists-keeps-Queen-bay.htmlCastle siege by tourists keeps Queen at bay[[Daily Mail]]2 August 2005The ballroom is the only room in the castle that may be viewed by the public.cite webhttp://www.balmoralcastle.com/admissions.htm2011 Admission ChargesBalmoral Estate23 January 2012
article.heading: Craigowan Lodge
article.paragraph: Craigowan Lodge is a seven-bedroomcite webhttp://news.stv.tv/east-central/108984-royals-in-scotland-palaces-paparazzi-and-garden-parties/Royals in Scotland: Palaces, paparazzi and garden partiesMichael MacLeodSTV Newsstone house approximately a mile from the main castle in Balmoral.cite webhttp://www.streetvi.com/en/map/gb/419235-Craigowan-Lodge/#/point/57.040842/-3.238704/0/0/0/Panorama of Lodgehttps://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/news/aberdeenshire/298492/queen-arrives-in-royal-deeside-for-holiday/More rustic than the castle, the lodge was often the home of Charles and Diana when they visited. Currently, it is used as quarters for very important guests.

In the obituary ofPrince Michael Andreevich of RussiaMichael Andreevich Romanoff, the highest-ranking member of the Russian imperial family at the time of his death in 2008, it was noted that his family spent most of World War II at Craigowan Lodge.cite newshttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article4922121.eceMichael Andreevich Romanoff: member of the Russian imperial familyLondonThe Times11 October 2008

The lodge has been in the news periodically since 2005, because Queen Elizabeth often spends the first few days of her summer holiday in the lodge.During each weekend of the summer the castle is a lucrative source of income from visiting tourists. Sometimes, the Queen arrives at Balmoral before the tourist visiting season is over.cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-357891/Castle-siege-tourists-keeps-Queen-bay.htmlCastle siege by tourists keeps Queen at bayLondonDaily MailJonathanBrocklebank2 August 2005
article.heading: In popular culture
article.paragraph: Queen Elizabeth was in residence at Balmoral at the time of thedeath of Diana, Princess of Walesin 1997. Her private discussions with Prime MinisterTony Blairwere dramatised in theStephen Frearsfilm,The Queen (film)The Queen(2006). The 1997 filmMrs. Brown (film)Mrs. Brownalso was based on events at Balmoral. In both films, however, substitute locations were used:Blairquhan CastleinThe Queen; andDuns CastleinMrs Brown.cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0436697/locationsFilming locations for ''The Queen''[[Internet Movie Database]]23 January 2012cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119280/locationsFilming locations for ''Mrs Brown''Internet Movie Database23 January 2012
